setMaxLengths.description:
Set the maximum lengths of the rope segments.

The physics module also imposes maximum values for the rope segments. If the parameters exceed these values, the maximum values are set instead of the requested values.

getGroundAnchors.description: Get the ground anchor positions in world coordinates.

setCategory.description: Sets the categories the fixture belongs to. There can be up to 16 categories represented as a number from 1 to 16.

getMask.description: Returns the category mask of the fixture.

isDestroyed.description: Gets whether the Fixture is destroyed. Destroyed fixtures cannot be used.

getRestitution.description: Returns the restitution of the fixture.

setRestitution.description: Sets the restitution of the fixture.

getDensity.description: Returns the density of the fixture.

testPoint.description: Checks if a point is inside the shape of the fixture.

getFriction.description: Returns the friction of the fixture.

setUserData.description:
Associates a Lua value with the fixture.

Use this function in one thread only.

getBoundingBox.description: Returns the points of the fixture bounding box. In case the fixture has multiple children a 1-based index can be specified. For example, a fixture will have multiple children with a chain shape.

setSensor.description:
Sets whether the fixture should act as a sensor.

Sensor do not produce collisions responses, but the begin and end callbacks will still be called for this fixture.

rayCast.description:
Casts a ray against the shape of the fixture and returns the surface normal vector and the line position where the ray hit. If the ray missed the shape, nil will be returned.

The ray starts on the first point of the input line and goes towards the second point of the line. The fourth argument is the maximum distance the ray is going to travel as a scale factor of the input line length.

The childIndex parameter is used to specify which child of a parent shape, such as a ChainShape, will be ray casted. For ChainShapes, the index of 1 is the first edge on the chain. Ray casting a parent shape will only test the child specified so if you want to test every shape of the parent, you must loop through all of its children.

The world position of the impact can be calculated by multiplying the line vector with the third return value and adding it to the line starting point.

hitx, hity = x1 + (x2 - x1) * fraction, y1 + (y2 - y1) * fraction

setMask.description:
Sets the category mask of the fixture. There can be up to 16 categories represented as a number from 1 to 16.

This fixture will collide with the fixtures that are in the selected categories if the other fixture also has a category of this fixture selected.

getShape.description:
Returns the shape of the fixture. This shape is a reference to the actual data used in the simulation. It's possible to change its values between timesteps.

Do not call any functions on this shape after the parent fixture has been destroyed. This shape will point to an invalid memory address and likely cause crashes if you interact further with it.

setFilterData.description:
Sets the filter data of the fixture.

Groups, categories, and mask can be used to define the collision behaviour of the fixture.

If two fixtures are in the same group they either always collide if the group is positive, or never collide if it's negative. If the group is zero or they do not match, then the contact filter checks if the fixtures select a category of the other fixture with their masks. The fixtures do not collide if that's not the case. If they do have each other's categories selected, the return value of the custom contact filter will be used. They always collide if none was set.

There can be up to 16 categories. Categories and masks are encoded as the bits of a 16-bit integer.

setDensity.description: Sets the density of the fixture. Call Body:resetMassData if this needs to take effect immediately.

isSensor.description: Returns whether the fixture is a sensor.

getFilterData.description: Returns the filter data of the fixture. Categories and masks are encoded as the bits of a 16-bit integer.

setFriction.description: Sets the friction of the fixture.

setGroupIndex.description:
Sets the group the fixture belongs to. Fixtures with the same group will always collide if the group is positive or never collide if it's negative. The group zero means no group.

The groups range from -32768 to 32767.

getUserData.description:
Returns the Lua value associated with this fixture.

Use this function in one thread only.

getBody.description: Returns the body to which the fixture is attached.

getGroupIndex.description:
Returns the group the fixture belongs to. Fixtures with the same group will always collide if the group is positive or never collide if it's negative. The group zero means no group.

The groups range from -32768 to 32767.

getCategory.description: Returns the categories the fixture belongs to.

getMassData.description: Returns the mass, its center and the rotational inertia.

getLineHeight.description: Gets the line height. This will be the value previously set by Font:setLineHeight, or 1.0 by default.

getWrap.description:
Gets formatting information for text, given a wrap limit.

This function accounts for newlines correctly (i.e. '\n').

variants.description: Gets whether the font can render a particular character.
Gets whether the font can render a particular character.

setFallbacks.description: Sets the fallback fonts. When the Font doesn't contain a glyph, it will substitute the glyph from the next subsequent fallback Fonts. This is akin to setting a "font stack" in Cascading Style Sheets (CSS).

getWidth.description: Determines the horizontal size a line of text needs. Does not support line-breaks.

getAscent.description: Gets the ascent of the Font. The ascent spans the distance between the baseline and the top of the glyph that reaches farthest from the baseline.

setFilter.description: Sets the filter mode for a font.

getHeight.description: Gets the height of the Font. The height of the font is the size including any spacing; the height which it will need.

setLineHeight.description: Sets the line height. When rendering the font in lines the actual height will be determined by the line height multiplied by the height of the font. The default is 1.0.

getBaseline.description: Gets the baseline of the Font. Most scripts share the notion of a baseline: an imaginary horizontal line on which characters rest. In some scripts, parts of glyphs lie below the baseline.

getFilter.description: Gets the filter mode for a font.

getDescent.description: Gets the descent of the Font. The descent spans the distance between the baseline and the lowest descending glyph in a typeface.

getSize.description: Gets the size of the Data.

getString.description: Gets the full Data as a string.

getPointer.description: Gets a pointer to the Data.

getDampingRatio.description: Returns the damping ratio of the joint.

variants.description: Sets the seed of the random number generator using the specified integer number.
Sets the seed of the random number generator using the specified integer number.
Get uniformly distributed pseudo-random number within [0, 1].
Get uniformly distributed pseudo-random integer number within [1, max].
Get uniformly distributed pseudo-random integer number within [min, max].

getState.description:
Gets the current state of the random number generator. This returns an opaque implementation-dependent string which is only useful for later use with RandomGenerator:setState.

This is different from RandomGenerator:getSeed in that getState gets the RandomGenerator's current state, whereas getSeed gets the previously set seed number.

The value of the state string does not depend on the current operating system.

getSeed.description:
Gets the state of the random number generator.

The state is split into two numbers due to Lua's use of doubles for all number values - doubles can't accurately represent integer values above 2^53.

setState.description:
Sets the current state of the random number generator. The value used as an argument for this function is an opaque implementation-dependent string and should only originate from a previous call to RandomGenerator:getState.

This is different from RandomGenerator:setSeed in that setState directly sets the RandomGenerator's current implementation-dependent state, whereas setSeed gives it a new seed value.

The effect of the state string does not depend on the current operating system.

randomNormal.description: Get a normally distributed pseudo random number.

rayCast.description:
Casts a ray against the shape and returns the surface normal vector and the line position where the ray hit. If the ray missed the shape, nil will be returned. The Shape can be transformed to get it into the desired position.

The ray starts on the first point of the input line and goes towards the second point of the line. The fourth argument is the maximum distance the ray is going to travel as a scale factor of the input line length.

The childIndex parameter is used to specify which child of a parent shape, such as a ChainShape, will be ray casted. For ChainShapes, the index of 1 is the first edge on the chain. Ray casting a parent shape will only test the child specified so if you want to test every shape of the parent, you must loop through all of its children.

The world position of the impact can be calculated by multiplying the line vector with the third return value and adding it to the line starting point.

hitx, hity = x1 + (x2 - x1) * fraction, y1 + (y2 - y1) * fraction

computeAABB.description: Returns the points of the bounding box for the transformed shape.

getRadius.description: Gets the radius of the shape.

computeMass.description: Computes the mass properties for the shape with the specified density.

getChildCount.description: Returns the number of children the shape has.

testPoint.description: Checks whether a point lies inside the shape. This is particularly useful for mouse interaction with the shapes. By looping through all shapes and testing the mouse position with this function, we can find which shapes the mouse touches.

getType.description: Gets a string representing the Shape. This function can be useful for conditional debug drawing.

variants.description: Gets the width of the CompressedImageData.
Gets the width of the CompressedImageData.
Gets the height of the CompressedImageData.
Gets the height of the CompressedImageData.
Gets the width and height of the CompressedImageData.
Gets the width and height of the CompressedImageData.

getFormat.description: Gets the format of the CompressedImageData.

getMipmapCount.description: Gets the number of mipmap levels in the CompressedImageData. The base mipmap level (original image) is included in the count.

getSegment.description: Gets a BezierCurve that corresponds to the specified segment of this BezierCurve.

renderSegment.description:
Get a list of coordinates on a specific part of the curve, to be used with love.graphics.line.

This function samples the Bézier curve using recursive subdivision. You can control the recursion depth using the depth parameter.

If you are just need to know the position on the curve given a parameter, use BezierCurve:evaluate.

getDerivative.description:
Get the derivative of the Bézier curve.

This function can be used to rotate sprites moving along a curve in the direction of the movement and compute the direction perpendicular to the curve at some parameter t.

getControlPointCount.description: Get the number of control points in the Bézier curve.

translate.description: Move the Bézier curve by an offset.

scale.description: Scale the Bézier curve by a factor.

render.description:
Get a list of coordinates to be used with love.graphics.line.

This function samples the Bézier curve using recursive subdivision. You can control the recursion depth using the depth parameter.

If you are just interested to know the position on the curve given a parameter, use BezierCurve:evaluate.

insertControlPoint.description: Insert control point as the new i-th control point. Existing control points from i onwards are pushed back by 1. Indices start with 1. Negative indices wrap around: -1 is the last control point, -2 the one before the last, etc.

getDegree.description: Get degree of the Bézier curve. The degree is equal to number-of-control-points - 1.

evaluate.description:
Evaluate Bézier curve at parameter t. The parameter must be between 0 and 1 (inclusive).

This function can be used to move objects along paths or tween parameters. However it should not be used to render the curve, see BezierCurve:render for that purpose.

getControlPoint.description: Get coordinates of the i-th control point. Indices start with 1.

setControlPoint.description: Set coordinates of the i-th control point. Indices start with 1.

rotate.description: Rotate the Bézier curve by an angle.

getDuration.description: Gets the duration of the Source. For streaming Sources it may not always be sample-accurate, and may return -1 if the duration cannot be determined at all.

getPosition.description: Gets the position of the Source.

getRolloff.description: Returns the rolloff factor of the source.

tell.description: Gets the currently playing position of the Source.

isPlaying.description: Returns whether the Source is playing.

getPitch.description: Gets the current pitch of the Source.

getVolume.description: Gets the current volume of the Source.

setVolumeLimits.description: Sets the volume limits of the source. The limits have to be numbers from 0 to 1.

setRolloff.description:
Sets the rolloff factor which affects the strength of the used distance attenuation.

Extended information and detailed formulas can be found in the chapter "3.4. Attenuation By Distance" of OpenAL 1.1 specification.

getChannelCount.description: Gets the number of channels in the Source. Only 1-channel (mono) Sources can use directional and positional effects.

getDirection.description: Gets the direction of the Source.

setVelocity.description:
Sets the velocity of the Source.

This does not change the position of the Source, but is used to calculate the doppler effect.

setAttenuationDistances.description: Sets the reference and maximum distance of the source.

clone.description:
Creates an identical copy of the Source in the stopped state.

Static Sources will use significantly less memory and take much less time to be created if Source:clone is used to create them instead of love.audio.newSource, so this method should be preferred when making multiple Sources which play the same sound.

Cloned Sources inherit all the set-able state of the original Source, but they are initialized stopped.

getAttenuationDistances.description: Returns the reference and maximum distance of the source.

setPitch.description: Sets the pitch of the Source.

setCone.description: Sets the Source's directional volume cones. Together with Source:setDirection, the cone angles allow for the Source's volume to vary depending on its direction.

isLooping.description: Returns whether the Source will loop.

setPosition.description: Sets the position of the Source.

getType.description: Gets the type (static or stream) of the Source.

getCone.description: Gets the Source's directional volume cones. Together with Source:setDirection, the cone angles allow for the Source's volume to vary depending on its direction.

setDirection.description: Sets the direction vector of the Source. A zero vector makes the source non-directional.

seek.description: Sets the playing position of the Source.

getVelocity.description: Gets the velocity of the Source.

setVolume.description: Sets the volume of the Source.

getVolumeLimits.description: Returns the volume limits of the source.

setLooping.description: Sets whether the Source should loop.

getPoints.description: Returns the local coordinates of the edge points.

getNextVertex.description:
Gets the vertex that establishes a connection to the next shape.

Setting next and previous EdgeShape vertices can help prevent unwanted collisions when a flat shape slides along the edge and moves over to the new shape.

getPreviousVertex.description:
Gets the vertex that establishes a connection to the previous shape.

Setting next and previous EdgeShape vertices can help prevent unwanted collisions when a flat shape slides along the edge and moves over to the new shape.

setNextVertex.description:
Sets a vertex that establishes a connection to the next shape.

This can help prevent unwanted collisions when a flat shape slides along the edge and moves over to the new shape.

setPreviousVertex.description:
Sets a vertex that establishes a connection to the previous shape.

This can help prevent unwanted collisions when a flat shape slides along the edge and moves over to the new shape.

getJointList.description: Returns a table with all joints.

getCallbacks.description: Returns functions for the callbacks during the world update.

getJointCount.description: Get the number of joints in the world.

queryBoundingBox.description: Calls a function for each fixture inside the specified area.

isDestroyed.description: Gets whether the World is destroyed. Destroyed worlds cannot be used.

getBodyList.description: Returns a table with all bodies.

getContactCount.description: Returns the number of contacts in the world.

getGravity.description: Get the gravity of the world.

getBodyCount.description: Get the number of bodies in the world.

rayCast.description: Casts a ray and calls a function for each fixtures it intersects.

update.description: Update the state of the world.

setCallbacks.description:
Sets functions for the collision callbacks during the world update.

Four Lua functions can be given as arguments. The value nil removes a function.

When called, each function will be passed three arguments. The first two arguments are the colliding fixtures and the third argument is the Contact between them. The PostSolve callback additionally gets the normal and tangent impulse for each contact point.

destroy.description:
Destroys the world, taking all bodies, joints, fixtures and their shapes with it.

An error will occur if you attempt to use any of the destroyed objects after calling this function.

getContactList.description: Returns a table with all contacts.

setSleepingAllowed.description:
Set the sleep behaviour of the world.

A sleeping body is much more efficient to simulate than when awake.

If sleeping is allowed, any body that has come to rest will sleep.

translateOrigin.description: Translates the World's origin. Useful in large worlds where floating point precision issues become noticeable at far distances from the origin.

isLocked.description:
Returns if the world is updating its state.

This will return true inside the callbacks from World:setCallbacks.

setGravity.description: Set the gravity of the world.

getContactFilter.description: Returns the function for collision filtering.

setContactFilter.description:
Sets a function for collision filtering.

If the group and category filtering doesn't generate a collision decision, this function gets called with the two fixtures as arguments. The function should return a boolean value where true means the fixtures will collide and false means they will pass through each other.

isSleepingAllowed.description: Returns the sleep behaviour of the world.

getStream.description: Gets the VideoStream object used for decoding and controlling the video.

play.description: Starts playing the Video. In order for the video to appear onscreen it must be drawn with love.graphics.draw.

getDimensions.description: Gets the width and height of the Video in pixels.

setSource.description: Sets the audio Source used for playing back the video's audio. The audio Source also controls playback speed and synchronization.

isPlaying.description: Gets whether the Video is currently playing.

tell.description: Gets the current playback position of the Video.

getWidth.description: Gets the width of the Video in pixels.

seek.description: Sets the current playback position of the Video.

setFilter.description: Sets the scaling filters used when drawing the Video.

getHeight.description: Gets the height of the Video in pixels.

rewind.description: Rewinds the Video to the beginning.

getFilter.description: Gets the scaling filters used when drawing the Video.

getSource.description: Gets the audio Source used for playing back the video's audio. May return nil if the video has no audio, or if Video:setSource is called with a nil argument.

variants.description:
Applies an impulse to a body. This makes a single, instantaneous addition to the body momentum.

An impulse pushes a body in a direction. A body with with a larger mass will react less. The reaction does not depend on the timestep, and is equivalent to applying a force continuously for 1 second. Impulses are best used to give a single push to a body. For a continuous push to a body it is better to use Body:applyForce.

If the position to apply the impulse is not given, it will act on the center of mass of the body. The part of the impulse not directed towards the center of mass will cause the body to spin (and depends on the rotational inertia).

Note that the impulse components and position must be given in world coordinates.

Applies an impulse to a body. This makes a single, instantaneous addition to the body momentum.

An impulse pushes a body in a direction. A body with with a larger mass will react less. The reaction does not depend on the timestep, and is equivalent to applying a force continuously for 1 second. Impulses are best used to give a single push to a body. For a continuous push to a body it is better to use Body:applyForce.

If the position to apply the impulse is not given, it will act on the center of mass of the body. The part of the impulse not directed towards the center of mass will cause the body to spin (and depends on the rotational inertia).

Note that the impulse components and position must be given in world coordinates.

isFixedRotation.description: Returns whether the body rotation is locked.

setActive.description:
Sets whether the body is active in the world.

An inactive body does not take part in the simulation. It will not move or cause any collisions.

isActive.description: Returns whether the body is actively used in the simulation.

isDestroyed.description: Gets whether the Body is destroyed. Destroyed bodies cannot be used.

getLocalCenter.description:
Get the center of mass position in local coordinates.

Use Body:getWorldCenter to get the center of mass in world coordinates.

setLinearDamping.description:
Sets the linear damping of a Body

See Body:getLinearDamping for a definition of linear damping.

Linear damping can take any value from 0 to infinity. It is recommended to stay between 0 and 0.1, though. Other values will make the objects look "floaty".

setLinearVelocity.description:
Sets a new linear velocity for the Body.

This function will not accumulate anything; any impulses previously applied since the last call to World:update will be lost.

getUserData.description: Returns the Lua value associated with this Body.

getMass.description: Get the mass of the body.

isSleepingAllowed.description: Returns the sleeping behaviour of the body.

setY.description: Set the y position of the body.

getWorldCenter.description:
Get the center of mass position in world coordinates.

Use Body:getLocalCenter to get the center of mass in local coordinates.

resetMassData.description: Resets the mass of the body by recalculating it from the mass properties of the fixtures.

getLinearDamping.description:
Gets the linear damping of the Body.

The linear damping is the rate of decrease of the linear velocity over time. A moving body with no damping and no external forces will continue moving indefinitely, as is the case in space. A moving body with damping will gradually stop moving.

Damping is not the same as friction - they can be modelled together. However, only damping is provided by Box2D (and LÖVE).

getLocalVector.description: Transform a vector from world coordinates to local coordinates.

destroy.description: Explicitly destroys the Body. When you don't have time to wait for garbage collection, this function may be used to free the object immediately, but note that an error will occur if you attempt to use the object after calling this function.

getLinearVelocity.description:
Gets the linear velocity of the Body from its center of mass.

The linear velocity is the rate of change of position over time.

If you need the rate of change of angle over time, use Body:getAngularVelocity. If you need to get the linear velocity of a point different from the center of mass:

Body:getLinearVelocityFromLocalPoint allows you to specify the point in local coordinates.

Body:getLinearVelocityFromWorldPoint allows you to specify the point in world coordinates.

variants.description:
Apply force to a Body.

A force pushes a body in a direction. A body with with a larger mass will react less. The reaction also depends on how long a force is applied: since the force acts continuously over the entire timestep, a short timestep will only push the body for a short time. Thus forces are best used for many timesteps to give a continuous push to a body (like gravity). For a single push that is independent of timestep, it is better to use Body:applyLinearImpulse.

If the position to apply the force is not given, it will act on the center of mass of the body. The part of the force not directed towards the center of mass will cause the body to spin (and depends on the rotational inertia).

Note that the force components and position must be given in world coordinates.

Apply force to a Body.

A force pushes a body in a direction. A body with with a larger mass will react less. The reaction also depends on how long a force is applied: since the force acts continuously over the entire timestep, a short timestep will only push the body for a short time. Thus forces are best used for many timesteps to give a continuous push to a body (like gravity). For a single push that is independent of timestep, it is better to use Body:applyLinearImpulse.

If the position to apply the force is not given, it will act on the center of mass of the body. The part of the force not directed towards the center of mass will cause the body to spin (and depends on the rotational inertia).

Note that the force components and position must be given in world coordinates.

getWorldPoints.description: Transforms multiple points from local coordinates to world coordinates.

getFixtureList.description: Returns a table with all fixtures.

setBullet.description:
Set the bullet status of a body.

There are two methods to check for body collisions:

at their location when the world is updated (default)

using continuous collision detection (CCD)

The default method is efficient, but a body moving very quickly may sometimes jump over another body without producing a collision. A body that is set as a bullet will use CCD. This is less efficient, but is guaranteed not to jump when moving quickly.

Note that static bodies (with zero mass) always use CCD, so your walls will not let a fast moving body pass through even if it is not a bullet.

applyAngularImpulse.description:
Applies an angular impulse to a body. This makes a single, instantaneous addition to the body momentum.

A body with with a larger mass will react less. The reaction does not depend on the timestep, and is equivalent to applying a force continuously for 1 second. Impulses are best used to give a single push to a body. For a continuous push to a body it is better to use Body:applyForce.

getMassData.description: Returns the mass, its center, and the rotational inertia.

setUserData.description:
Associates a Lua value with the Body.

To delete the reference, explicitly pass nil.

getPosition.description:
Get the position of the body.

Note that this may not be the center of mass of the body.

isBullet.description:
Get the bullet status of a body.

There are two methods to check for body collisions:

at their location when the world is updated (default)

using continuous collision detection (CCD)

The default method is efficient, but a body moving very quickly may sometimes jump over another body without producing a collision. A body that is set as a bullet will use CCD. This is less efficient, but is guaranteed not to jump when moving quickly.

Note that static bodies (with zero mass) always use CCD, so your walls will not let a fast moving body pass through even if it is not a bullet.

setPosition.description:
Set the position of the body.

Note that this may not be the center of mass of the body.

getX.description: Get the x position of the body in world coordinates.

setAngularVelocity.description:
Sets the angular velocity of a Body.

The angular velocity is the rate of change of angle over time.

This function will not accumulate anything; any impulses previously applied since the last call to World:update will be lost.

setInertia.description: Set the inertia of a body.

applyTorque.description:
Apply torque to a body.

Torque is like a force that will change the angular velocity (spin) of a body. The effect will depend on the rotational inertia a body has.

setFixedRotation.description:
Set whether a body has fixed rotation.

Bodies with fixed rotation don't vary the speed at which they rotate.

setAwake.description: Wakes the body up or puts it to sleep.

setAngularDamping.description:
Sets the angular damping of a Body.

See Body:getAngularDamping for a definition of angular damping.

Angular damping can take any value from 0 to infinity. It is recommended to stay between 0 and 0.1, though. Other values will look unrealistic.

getAngle.description:
Get the angle of the body.

The angle is measured in radians. If you need to transform it to degrees, use math.deg.

A value of 0 radians will mean "looking to the right". Although radians increase counter-clockwise, the y-axis points down so it becomes clockwise from our point of view.

getJointList.description: Returns a table containing the Joints attached to this Body.

setSleepingAllowed.description: Sets the sleeping behaviour of the body.

isAwake.description: Returns the sleep status of the body.

setAngle.description:
Set the angle of the body.

The angle is measured in radians. If you need to transform it from degrees, use math.rad.

A value of 0 radians will mean "looking to the right". Although radians increase counter-clockwise, the y-axis points down so it becomes clockwise from our point of view.

It is possible to cause a collision with another body by changing its angle.

getAngularDamping.description:
Gets the Angular damping of the Body

The angular damping is the rate of decrease of the angular velocity over time: A spinning body with no damping and no external forces will continue spinning indefinitely. A spinning body with damping will gradually stop spinning.

Damping is not the same as friction - they can be modelled together. However, only damping is provided by Box2D (and LÖVE).

Damping parameters should be between 0 and infinity, with 0 meaning no damping, and infinity meaning full damping. Normally you will use a damping value between 0 and 0.1.

getY.description: Get the y position of the body in world coordinates.

getLinearVelocityFromLocalPoint.description:
Get the linear velocity of a point on the body.

The linear velocity for a point on the body is the velocity of the body center of mass plus the velocity at that point from the body spinning.

The point on the body must given in local coordinates. Use Body:getLinearVelocityFromWorldPoint to specify this with world coordinates.

getLinearVelocityFromWorldPoint.description:
Get the linear velocity of a point on the body.

The linear velocity for a point on the body is the velocity of the body center of mass plus the velocity at that point from the body spinning.

The point on the body must given in world coordinates. Use Body:getLinearVelocityFromLocalPoint to specify this with local coordinates.

getWorldVector.description: Transform a vector from local coordinates to world coordinates.

getLocalPoint.description: Transform a point from world coordinates to local coordinates.

getContactList.description: Gets a list of all Contacts attached to the Body.

setX.description: Set the x position of the body.

getWorld.description: Gets the World the body lives in.

getAngularVelocity.description:
Get the angular velocity of the Body.

The angular velocity is the rate of change of angle over time.

It is changed in World:update by applying torques, off centre forces/impulses, and angular damping. It can be set directly with Body:setAngularVelocity.

If you need the rate of change of position over time, use Body:getLinearVelocity.

setGravityScale.description: Sets a new gravity scale factor for the body.

getInertia.description:
Gets the rotational inertia of the body.

The rotational inertia is how hard is it to make the body spin.

getType.description: Returns the type of the body.

getWorldPoint.description: Transform a point from local coordinates to world coordinates.

type.description: Gets the type of the object as a string.

typeOf.description: Checks whether an object is of a certain type. If the object has the type with the specified name in its hierarchy, this function will return true.

getFilename.description: Gets the filename of the FileData.

getExtension.description: Gets the extension of the FileData.

getWidth.description: Gets the width of the ImageData in pixels.

getHeight.description: Gets the height of the ImageData in pixels.

paste.description: Paste into ImageData from another source ImageData.

encode.description: Encodes the ImageData and optionally writes it to the save directory.

getDimensions.description: Gets the width and height of the ImageData in pixels.

mapPixel.description:
Transform an image by applying a function to every pixel.

This function is a higher order function. It takes another function as a parameter, and calls it once for each pixel in the ImageData.

The function parameter is called with six parameters for each pixel in turn. The parameters are numbers that represent the x and y coordinates of the pixel and its red, green, blue and alpha values. The function parameter can return up to four number values, which become the new r, g, b and a values of the pixel. If the function returns fewer values, the remaining components are set to 0.

getPixel.description:
Gets the color of a pixel at a specific position in the image.

Valid x and y values start at 0 and go up to image width and height minus 1. Non-integer values are floored.

setPixel.description:
Sets the color of a pixel at a specific position in the image.

Valid x and y values start at 0 and go up to image width and height minus 1.

getMaxLength.description: Gets the maximum length of a RopeJoint.

setMaxLength.description: Sets the maximum length of a RopeJoint.

getLength.description: Gets the equilibrium distance between the two Bodies.

setLength.description: Sets the equilibrium distance between the two Bodies.

transformPoint.description:
Applies the Transform object's transformation to the given 2D position.

This effectively converts the given position from global coordinates into the local coordinate space of the Transform.

clone.description: Creates a new copy of this Transform.

shear.description: Applies a shear factor (skew) to the Transform's coordinate system. This method does not reset any previously applied transformations.

getMatrix.description: Gets the internal 4x4 transformation matrix stored by this Transform. The matrix is returned in row-major order.

scale.description: Scales the Transform's coordinate system. This method does not reset any previously applied transformations.

translate.description: Applies a translation to the Transform's coordinate system. This method does not reset any previously applied transformations.

setTransformation.description: Resets the Transform to the specified transformation parameters.

variants.description: Directly sets the Transform's internal 4x4 transformation matrix.
Directly sets the Transform's internal 4x4 transformation matrix.
Directly sets the Transform's internal 4x4 transformation matrix.
Directly sets the Transform's internal 4x4 transformation matrix.

reset.description: Resets the Transform to an identity state. All previously applied transformations are erased.

inverseTransformPoint.description:
Applies the reverse of the Transform object's transformation to the given 2D position.

This effectively converts the given position from the local coordinate space of the Transform into global coordinates.

One use of this method can be to convert a screen-space mouse position into global world coordinates, if the given Transform has transformations applied that are used for a camera system in-game.

apply.description: Applies the given other Transform object to this one.

inverse.description: Creates a new Transform containing the inverse of this Transform.

rotate.description: Applies a rotation to the Transform's coordinate system. This method does not reset any previously applied transformations.

setBuffer.description: Sets the buffer mode for a file opened for writing or appending. Files with buffering enabled will not write data to the disk until the buffer size limit is reached, depending on the buffer mode.

flush.description: Flushes any buffered written data in the file to the disk.

getBuffer.description: Gets the buffer mode of a file.

tell.description: Returns the position in the file.

getFilename.description: Gets the filename that the File object was created with. If the file object originated from the love.filedropped callback, the filename will be the full platform-dependent file path.

isEOF.description: Gets whether end-of-file has been reached.

seek.description: Seek to a position in a file.

lines.description: Iterate over all the lines in a file

read.description: Read a number of bytes from a file.

isOpen.description: Gets whether the file is open.

open.description:
Open the file for write, read or append.

If you are getting the error message "Could not set write directory", try setting the save directory. This is done either with love.filesystem.setIdentity or by setting the identity field in love.conf.

getMode.description: Gets the FileMode the file has been opened with.

getWrap.description:
Gets the wrapping properties of an Image.

This function returns the currently set horizontal and vertical wrapping modes for the image.

getDimensions.description: Gets the width and height of the Image.

setWrap.description:
Sets the wrapping properties of an Image.

This function sets the way an Image is repeated when it is drawn with a Quad that is larger than the image's extent. An image may be clamped or set to repeat in both horizontal and vertical directions. Clamped images appear only once, but repeated ones repeat as many times as there is room in the Quad.

If you use a Quad that is larger than the image extent and do not use repeated tiling, there may be an unwanted visual effect of the image stretching all the way to fill the Quad. If this is the case, setting Image:getWrap("repeat", "repeat") for all the images to be repeated, and using Quad of appropriate size will result in the best visual appearance.

getWidth.description: Gets the width of the Image.

getFlags.description: Gets the flags used when the image was created.

setFilter.description: Sets the filter mode for an image.

getHeight.description: Gets the height of the Image.

getMipmapFilter.description: Gets the mipmap filter mode for an Image.

variants.description:
Sets the mipmap filter mode for an Image.

Mipmapping is useful when drawing an image at a reduced scale. It can improve performance and reduce aliasing issues.

In 0.10.0 and newer, the Image must be created with the mipmaps flag enabled for the mipmap filter to have any effect.
Disables mipmap filtering.

getFilter.description: Gets the filter mode for an image.

replacePixels.description: Replaces the contents of an Image.

getViewport.description: Gets the current viewport of this Quad.

setViewport.description: Sets the texture coordinates according to a viewport.

getTextureDimensions.description: Gets reference texture dimensions initially specified in love.graphics.newQuad.

getFont.description: Gets the Font used with the Text object.

variants.description: Gets the width and height of the text in pixels.
Gets the width and height of a specific sub-string that was previously added to the Text object.
Adds additional formatted / colored text to the Text object at the specified position.
Adds additional formatted / colored text to the Text object at the specified position.

clear.description: Clears the contents of the Text object.

variants.description: Gets the width of the text in pixels.
Gets the width of a specific sub-string that was previously added to the Text object.
Replaces the contents of the Text object with a new formatted string.
Replaces the contents of the Text object with a new formatted string.
Clears the contents of the Text object.
Gets the height of the text in pixels.
Gets the height of a specific sub-string that was previously added to the Text object.

setFont.description: Replaces the Font used with the text.

variants.description: Replaces the contents of the Text object with a new unformatted string.
Replaces the contents of the Text object with a new unformatted string.
Adds additional colored text to the Text object at the specified position.
Adds additional colored text to the Text object at the specified position.

getVibration.description: Gets the current vibration motor strengths on a Joystick with rumble support.

isConnected.description: Gets whether the Joystick is connected.

variants.description: Gets the button, axis or hat that a virtual gamepad input is bound to.
Gets the button, axis or hat that a virtual gamepad input is bound to.

getAxes.description: Gets the direction of each axis.

isVibrationSupported.description: Gets whether the Joystick supports vibration.

getGUID.description: Gets a stable GUID unique to the type of the physical joystick which does not change over time. For example, all Sony Dualshock 3 controllers in OS X have the same GUID. The value is platform-dependent.

getID.description: Gets the joystick's unique identifier. The identifier will remain the same for the life of the game, even when the Joystick is disconnected and reconnected, but it will change when the game is re-launched.

getAxis.description: Gets the direction of an axis.

getHatCount.description: Gets the number of hats on the joystick.

getGamepadAxis.description: Gets the direction of a virtual gamepad axis. If the Joystick isn't recognized as a gamepad or isn't connected, this function will always return 0.

variants.description: Sets the vibration motor speeds on a Joystick with rumble support.
Sets the vibration motor speeds on a Joystick with rumble support.
Sets the vibration motor speeds on a Joystick with rumble support.

isGamepadDown.description: Checks if a virtual gamepad button on the Joystick is pressed. If the Joystick is not recognized as a Gamepad or isn't connected, then this function will always return false.

isGamepad.description:
Gets whether the Joystick is recognized as a gamepad. If this is the case, the Joystick's buttons and axes can be used in a standardized manner across different operating systems and joystick models via Joystick:getGamepadAxis and related functions.

LÖVE automatically recognizes most popular controllers with a similar layout to the Xbox 360 controller as gamepads, but you can add more with love.joystick.setGamepadMapping.

getAxisCount.description: Gets the number of axes on the joystick.

isDown.description:
Checks if a button on the Joystick is pressed.

LÖVE 0.9.0 had a bug which required the button indices passed to Joystick:isDown to be 0-based instead of 1-based, for example button 1 would be 0 for this function. It was fixed in 0.9.1.

getName.description: Gets the name of the joystick.

getButtonCount.description: Gets the number of buttons on the joystick.

getHat.description: Gets the direction of the Joystick's hat.

getType.description: Gets the type of the Cursor.

getAxis.description: Gets the world-space axis vector of the Wheel Joint.

getJointSpeed.description: Returns the current joint translation speed.

getMotorSpeed.description: Returns the speed of the motor.

getMotorTorque.description: Returns the current torque on the motor.

setMotorSpeed.description: Sets a new speed for the motor.

setMotorEnabled.description: Starts and stops the joint motor.

setMaxMotorTorque.description: Sets a new maximum motor torque.

getPoints.description:
Get the local coordinates of the polygon's vertices.

This function has a variable number of return values. It can be used in a nested fashion with love.graphics.polygon.

This function may have up to 16 return values, since it returns two values for each vertex in the polygon. In other words, it can return the coordinates of up to 8 points.

getDuration.description: Gets the duration of the sound file. It may not always be sample-accurate, and it may return -1 if the duration cannot be determined at all.

getChannelCount.description: Returns the number of channels in the stream.

getSampleRate.description: Returns the sample rate of the Decoder.

getBitDepth.description: Returns the number of bits per sample.

setRadius.description: Sets the radius of the circle.

getPoint.description: Gets the center point of the circle shape.

setPoint.description: Sets the location of the center of the circle shape.

getRadius.description: Gets the radius of the circle shape.

getAnchors.description: Get the anchor points of the joint.

getBodies.description: Gets the bodies that the Joint is attached to.

isDestroyed.description: Gets whether the Joint is destroyed. Destroyed joints cannot be used.

destroy.description: Explicitly destroys the Joint. When you don't have time to wait for garbage collection, this function may be used to free the object immediately, but note that an error will occur if you attempt to use the object after calling this function.

getCollideConnected.description: Gets whether the connected Bodies collide.

setUserData.description:
Associates a Lua value with the Joint.

To delete the reference, explicitly pass nil.

getReactionForce.description: Gets the reaction force on Body 2 at the joint anchor.

getUserData.description: Returns the Lua value associated with this Joint.

getReactionTorque.description: Returns the reaction torque on the second body.

getType.description: Gets a string representing the type.

push.description:
Send a message to the thread Channel.

See Variant for the list of supported types.

variants.description:
Send a message to the thread Channel and wait for a thread to accept it.

See Variant for the list of supported types.

Send a message to the thread Channel and wait for a thread to accept it.

See Variant for the list of supported types.

hasRead.description: Gets whether a pushed value has been popped or otherwise removed from the Channel.

clear.description: Clears all the messages in the Channel queue.

performAtomic.description:
Executes the specified function atomically with respect to this Channel.

Calling multiple methods in a row on the same Channel is often useful. However if multiple Threads are calling this Channel's methods at the same time, the different calls on each Thread might end up interleaved (e.g. one or more of the second thread's calls may happen in between the first thread's calls.)

This method avoids that issue by making sure the Thread calling the method has exclusive access to the Channel until the specified function has returned.

pop.description:
Retrieves the value of a Channel message and removes it from the message queue.

It returns nil if there are no messages in the queue.

peek.description:
Retrieves the value of a Channel message, but leaves it in the queue.

It returns nil if there's no message in the queue.
